course_title_2026: The Object in the Art Museum
best_comment: Take this class (please please please remember to apply on time – it is popular and hard to get in but if you demonstrate your own interesting perspectives you stand a great shot!)! This class had about 5–6 undergrads and the rest (8) were grad students across HAA, HKS, HLS, and the Divinity School. Everyone brought such interesting ideas and perspectives to every class. Joachim and Kate are incredible professors and you will gain a totally new appreciation for art and art museums by learning everything from art dealers to provenance to restoration and everything in between.  The weekly assignments and readings aren't too long but to get the most out of the course you should do them. The major project of the course is a 10 page paper on an object you pick (that will be going into an exhibit – our kunstkamer objects go on display in July 2025, more on that later) and it's super interesting.On the objects, this was mainly about Dutch 16–17th century art. Since our collection is going up I'm not sure what the focus will be but it's worth reaching out and asking because if you aren't at all interested in the theme you won't get as much out of the course as someone who is – like we all became experts on Dutch 16–17th century art. All in all, my favorite course at Harvard and my only Arts and Humanities course and what an incredible way to finish up college.

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! This is arguably the only course at Harvard where I received the academic experience I've been searching for. I enjoyed learning about race and ethnicity (my understanding of which has completely transformed) through several distinct, interesting cases across time and space. best_comment: If you're really into moral/ethical philosophy, I think you will absolutely love this class. If you're only kind of interested like I was/am, you'll have a good time, but things can get a little boring. The class is VERY formulaic week to week: you read a few texts, Seth explains them in lecture, and you discuss them in section. There is very little throughout the semester to break up this routine, which can make the whole course just blend into one big blob of philosophy. That being said, I still give this class a very positive review. Seth is very intentional with what/how he teaches, and it's obvious that one of his goals is for each of his students to leave his class as better people. He's also just a cool dude, and makes the whole class a super chill vibe. I also really like how major assignments are structured. You have to write two ~1500 word essays which are based more on your own thinking and perspective than a standard research paper. They were overall really enjoyable to write, and the grading is pretty friendly if you do a good job. Great class! If you're looking for a fun elective which is easy, but not a joke, and you want to learn something along the way, this is an excellent choice.
best_comment_short: They were overall really enjoyable to write, and the grading is pretty friendly if you do a good job.
best_comment_first: If you're really into moral/ethical philosophy, I think you will absolutely love this class.

course_title_2026: US Environmental Policy and Policymaking: The Role of Congress, EPA, Stakeholders, and Courts
best_comment: I HIGHLY recommend this course to anyone who has any interest in government structures, climate mitigation/adaptation,  and the environment. Professor Jenks, though very thorough in communicating the various obstacles and challenges of environmental + public health protection, maintains an optimistic, forward–thinking outlook that's incredibly refreshing compared to the doom and gloom that sometimes pervades environmental science courses.  The once–a–week section allows you to engage deeply with the material and spend more time thinking about issues and solutions rather than completing assignments as a means to an end.  Additionally, the different perspectives of weekly guest speakers offer a view into the practical applications of everything you learn about. The assignments are challenging, but feedback is very helpful and grading is fair. I walk away from this course not only feeling more confident about my ability to engage with big questions and complex solutions but also more prepared to engage with challenging source materials and write policy memorandums. Take this course if you want to grow in your understanding, to grow as a writer, and to grow as an aspiring agent of change!
